content: The "Child Support Enforcement Improvements Act of 1993" allows depository institutions to provide financial records to state child support enforcement agencies without liability. The "Child Support Enforcement Improvements Act of 1993" allows depository institutions to disclose financial records to state child support enforcement agencies without liability. State agencies can only use the financial records for establishing, modifying, or enforcing child support obligations. Civil damages may apply for unauthorized disclosure by state officers or employees. Civil damages may be sought against a State if an officer or employee knowingly or negligently discloses a financial record in violation of the law. Liability does not apply if the disclosure was made in good faith but based on an erroneous interpretation. Damages in such cases are determined by the court. The defendant is liable to the plaintiff for unauthorized disclosure of financial records, including actual damages, punitive damages for willful disclosure or gross negligence, and the costs of the action. Definitions for terms like "depository institution," "financial record," and "State child support enforcement agency" are provided in this section. The term "State child support enforcement agency" refers to a State agency that administers a program for establishing and enforcing child support obligations. State child support enforcement agencies can access and use consumer reports in child support cases. State child support enforcement agencies can access consumer reports for establishing, modifying, or enforcing child support obligations if paternity is established or acknowledged by the consumer, and the agency provides written notice to the consumer beforehand. State child support enforcement agencies must notify consumers before obtaining a consumer report and certify that all necessary requirements have been fulfilled. Additionally, a State child support enforcement agency is defined as a State agency that administers a program for establishing and enforcing child support obligations. SEC. 4. HEALTH CARE SUPPORT. The text chunk discusses the inclusion of health care coverage in child support orders, requiring orders to comply with state guidelines for health care costs of the child. The text chunk discusses the expedited consideration and disposition of noncompliance allegations regarding health care costs in child support orders. States must establish guidelines for health care coverage of children under child support orders to meet minimum standards. The Secretary will set minimum standards for guidelines on health care coverage for children under child support orders in the State, including the contents of the order, responsibility distribution, and insurance provisions. The Secretary will establish guidelines for health care coverage for children under child support orders, including insurance provisions, denial of coverage circumstances, penalties for non-compliance, and consideration of changes in parents' circumstances. The Secretary will establish guidelines for health care coverage for children under child support orders, considering the best interests of the child, parents' financial circumstances, and cost-effectiveness. Regulations must be proposed within 9 months and finalized within 14 months after the enactment of the Act. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will issue final regulations within 14 months to implement amendments related to child support orders requiring health insurance for children. Successful enforcement of this provision will be considered support collection from the absent parent for incentive payment program inclusion. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will issue regulations within 6 months to implement amendments regarding child support orders for health insurance. The amount collected from absent parents for providing health insurance to children will be considered as support. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study to determine incentives for States to enforce noncustodial parents' obligations to pay for children's health and dental expenses. A report on the results will be submitted to the House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee within 12 months of the Act's enactment. The study results on incentives for States to enforce noncustodial parents' obligations for children's health expenses will be submitted to the House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee. SEC. 5. ANNUAL REPORTS ON STATE COMPLIANCE WITH CHILD SUPPORT TIME LIMITS. Amends the Social Security Act to include compliance standards for states. SEC. 6. EMPLOYERS WITHHOLDING WAGES FOR CHILD SUPPORT MUST PAY STATE WITHIN 10 DAYS. Employers face penalties for late payments. Amendment to the Social Security Act requires employers to pay child support within 10 days or face a $1,000 penalty to the State. Penalties collected must be used for the State plan approved under section 454. Effective date of the amendment is specified. The amendment to the Social Security Act mandates employers to promptly pay child support or incur a $1,000 penalty to the State. Penalties collected must fund the State plan approved under section 454. The effective date of the amendment is upon enactment, applying to wages paid thereafter and payments under part D of title IV for specified calendar quarters. The State plan must meet additional requirements imposed by amendments to the Social Security Act. Failure to meet these requirements before a specified deadline will not be considered non-compliance solely based on timing. Each year of a 2-year legislative session is deemed a separate regular session of the State legislature. SEC. 7. NATIONAL PARENT LOCATOR NETWORK. The Social Security Act is amended to expand the Parent Locator Service into a national network, allowing States to locate absent parents who owe child support or are subject to visitation orders by accessing records from other agencies and Federal sources. The Parent Locator Service is expanded into a national network, allowing States to access records from other agencies and Federal sources to locate absent parents who owe child support or are subject to visitation orders. This includes accessing files of other States, providing online and batch processing of locate requests, and directing requests to individual States or Federal agencies. The Parent Locator Service is expanded into a national network, allowing States to access records from other agencies and Federal sources to locate absent parents who owe child support or are subject to visitation orders. This includes providing a maximum 48-hour turnaround time for information requests and ensuring ready access to court information through computer terminals. The Parent Locator Service is expanded nationally to help States locate absent parents for child support or visitation orders.
